distinct from the 
            
              mistrel
              minstrel
            , whose words are printed.

For when familiar 
            
              lettres
              letters
             are written in Biblical prose
there must be a barrier between what is sayable and what
insayable. There is a limit to what can be put
But then
into words. He cannot talk; he cannot sing. At the beginning

of the sixteenth 
            
              cnstury
              century
             he exists; the printing press has
[with?]
given him a name; but he is still unspecialised.

The man who stands outside desiring by some impulse to 
            
              obsev
              observe
, to state, rather than to take part, is not yet wholly

writer, wholly musician or 
            
              whllly
              wholly
             painter. It seems possible

that the great English art 
            
              ma
              may
             not be the art of words.
that sees exactly

He still has the exact 
            
              observan
              observant
             eye; his ear is stimulated
by the sound of words spoken aloud. His words must have body
words

and 
            
              substnace
              substance
            , He must make them  
            
              sornous
              sonorous
            , since they are to
be read out aloud. I spent most of my time" wrote Lady

Ann Clifford "in 
            
              playin
              playing
             at Glecko and hearing Moll Neville
read the ....Rivers used to read to me in
Montaignes Essays and Moll Neville in the Faery Queen."

Futher
              Further
            , words must 
              
                yeild
                yield
               themselves move easily to the lilt
of the singing voice, to the virginals, to the lute. The
For the English were [always?] singing & playing

Eoglish
              English
             were a musical race. When 
            
              Londonwas
              London was
             burning
Pepys noted that "hardly one lighter or boat in three
that had the goods of a house in it, but there was a pair
of virginals in it." These were the influences that
Music moved
told upon the poet; Under neath the words: the old words
the words in

the new words, the 
            
              Frechand
              French and
             the Latin moved the music.
No grammar bound them tightly to gether. They could be read
aloud; danced to and sung to. But they could not follow the
His senses are
attuned then:
he sees within
shadow.
the pace of the speaking voice. They could not enter into
the private world.
Spenser then --"a little man with short hair,

a small 
                  
                    vband
                    band
                   and cuffs" standing on the threshold of the

a small 
                  
                    vband
                    band
                   and cuffs" standing on the threshold of the

"gay and sumptuous house" at 
                  
                    enshurst
                    Penshurst
                  , was separate

from Anon the 
                  
                    misntre
                    minstrel
                  ; and from 
                  
                    Holmshed
                    Holinshed
                   the Chronicler;

He was separate too from his 
                
                  adueince
                  audience
                . But the book which

had given him his 
                
                  sepatare
                  separate
                 existence had brought into being
a little group of readers. That audience began at once to

exert its pressure. What is the book that will 
                
                  plase
                  please

my patron Sir Philip 
                
                  Sidmey
                  Sidney
                ? What is the theme that will

recommend itself to the Queen? At once come into 
                
                  ecistence
                  existence
                 all

those 
                
                  iunnmerable
                  innumerable
                 influences that are to tug and distort and
thwart; as too they are to stimulate and draw out. The
a nameless, a wandering voice [combined?] with his audience
poet is no longer a homeless being. He is surrounded
He is played upon by others

with an 
                
                  atmopshere
                  atmosphere
                . He subjects his inspiration to outside
influences. Some are visible to himself only; others
only show thems lves when time has past. They become more and
more complex. A the book goes out into a more and more
numerous, a more and more divided audience. &

Some According to its education to its wealth to its 
                
                  pverty
                  poverty

theaudi nce
                  the audience
                 begins to demand what it satisfies its own needs
Some need poetry; others history; others a story to make
them forget the drabness of their lives. The thing that
ththe writer has to say becomes increasingly cumbered.
